content.description: Mostly fists to hands and scrambling over weird blocks to top it off. Bit grainy at top.
content.protection: Double up on hand and fist sized cams.

content.description: Establishing into the wide is the hard part. Squirming up is the rest.
content.location: Far left side of West Point behind the Pine tree. To get down, 4th class up to top and rappel from anchor.

climbs.name: MASH
climbs.fa: Enrico Saladino, Clay Lippincott, Nathan Young

content.description:
Slightly overhanging hand crack to vertical face. The fun does not end until the anchors. 

  To get the full effect, stay in the crack the whole way up and don't use the block at the corner.
content.location:
This route is on the direct South side of West Point. If you are at Butter Bars walk to the west and you will find it. 

  Rap anchors are located at the top. They are difficult to get to in order to set up a top rope if you don't climb the route, but it can be done if you are careful.

content.description: This is the first part of Major Tom before it gets hard. As you exit the off-width crack into a ledge, you will see the chain anchors shared with Offshore Wind on the left. Starts with a nice hand crack that ends too soon, followed by a squeeze chimney that turns into an offwidth at the end. The crux is getting out of the crack into the ledge.

climbs.name: Major Tom
climbs.fa: FA: Mark Geikenjoyner, Manny Rangel; FFA: Jordan Mabrey , Mike Robinson, 1/18

content.description: The first part is wide, up to #5 and the end is overhung tight fingers. Both difficult patches; I got a sit down rest at top of wide crack.
content.protection: Several finger cams, single cams to #5.
content.location: This is the left of two prominent cracks in center of wall. It has an obvious finger crack shooting up and right to top.

content.description: The final traverse was very difficult, jams ok but feet non-existent as in Lt. Dan's. The first part of crack was no slouch either but much easier.
content.protection: double rack to single #4, #5. First part is hands to wide hands.
content.location: Start same as Col. Custer but traverse left at its end on difficult horizontal instead of finishing up and right.

climbs.name: Jesus loves you, but I don’t

content.description: TradPrincess Eden did the FFA on February 7th, 2021.Start with a finger crack/layback to get to the roof. The crux is getting established on top of the roof. From there you get inside the off-width with good holds to the top.
content.protection: The first section takes .4 to .75 cams. Two #5 for the crux, and two #6 for the rest of the route.
content.location: Crack to the left (facing the rock) of Major Tom.

climbs.name: Hail Satan
climbs.fa: Ben Albrecht, Carlos Villanueva, January 2021  FFA tradprincess eden

content.description: You want to tickle something wide? You want to get some of your body parts stuck while your groveling a piece off your rack. Do you love overhanging odd ball, painful, jams? Well this wonderland of stacks and body part jams will definitely appease your need for self inflicted pain! Some offwidth leads to epic jugs, then around a small corner into the business. 15’ of continuous climbing in a 3” - 6” crack!ENJOY!
content.protection: 1 - 3 cams. Double 4s, triple 5s, and a single 6!
content.location: Head to West Point from whichever area you park. On the left side of the crag. You can’t miss the start of the 2 off widths in a corner. This is the left offwidth and is very aesthetic looking!

content.description: The squeeze part is most intimidating but not that hard.
content.protection: .5 to #5 (single rack) but FA only used 3 pieces.
content.location: On West face of West Point; approach by walking right around East face to base of route.

content.description: The first part of the crack begins below the large roof on the right side of South face. This dihedral bends to the right at top and then the face traverse to the arete keeps it moving.
content.protection: #2, #3 (3), #4 (2), slings and quickdraw for one bolt. Bolted anchor; replaced old bolt.
content.location: Right side of SE face, visible from the trail.

content.description: I thought the crux was moving left under the roof; getting established there was committing.
content.protection: Doubles to single #4,#5 cams and nuts; slings etc
content.location: Begin on far right at a hand crack through brittle rock. Boulder up this to a wide crack that eases up to a short traverse left then a squeeze to the main roof. Traverse under this to the ledge and belay here (clip bolt first). Bring your second and have him do the face moves (with bolt) to gain the arete. Chain anchor.

content.description:
This crag is south facing and is perfect in winter. It has some hard cracks in 75' that go from fingers to wide. The rock is very good, with some exceptions. 

  Nobody climbs here. One old bolt on the right side exists. Needs replacing.
